facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1535 of 1968 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1535 of 1968. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 1, 1967 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 52 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 1, 1967 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 52 of 1962.

facts.text: The assessee is a Private Limited Company.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a Private Limited Company and at the relevant time,, it was under voluntary liquidation.

facts.text: Assessee was incorporated in June 1945 by converting an erstwhile partnership firm into a Private Limited Company.

anchor.surface_text: It was incorporated in June 1945 by companyverting an erstwhile partnership firm into a Private Limited Company.

facts.text: The partnership firm entered into a managing agency agreement on June 15,1933 with The Century Spinning and Manufacturing Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The partnership firm had entered into a managing agency agreement on June 15,1933 with a Public Limited Company called The Century Spinning and Manufacturing Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Under the agreement, the assessee was to continue as managing agents for a minimum period of 21 years.

anchor.surface_text: Under the said agreement, the assessee was to companytinue as managing agents for a minimum period of 21 years and thereafter until that firm chose to resign

facts.text: Agreement provided minimum remuneration of Rs. 6,000/- a month or additional to make 10% of gross profits.

anchor.surface_text: During the period the assessee companytinued to act as the managing agents the agreement provided, that the managing agents will get a minimum remuneration of Rs. 6,000/- a month and if its remuneration is found at the close of the year to be less than 10 per cent of the gross profit of the companypany, the managing agents were to be paid a further additional sum to make the aggregate remuneration received by it equal to 10 percent of the gross profit of the companypany for that year.

facts.text: If services terminated before 21 years except per clause 15, entitled to compensation per clause 14.

anchor.surface_text: The Agreement further provided that if the managing agents services were terminated before the period of 21 years stipulated in the agreement except for reasons mentioned in clause 15 of the agreement the managing agents would be entitled to receive from the managed companypany as companypensation or liquidated damages for the loss of office the sum mentioned in clause 14 of the agreement.

facts.text: In about April 1951, a large holding of the managed company was acquired by a group of shareholders hostile to the managing agents.

anchor.surface_text: In about April 1951, a large holding of the managed companypany was acquired by a group of shareholders who were hostile to the managing agents.

facts.text: On April 23, 1951, Directors of the managed company passed a resolution terminating the services of the assessee as managing agents.

anchor.surface_text: On April 23, 1951, the Directors of the managed companypany passed a resolution terminating the services of the assessee firm as managing agents.

facts.text: Resolution affirmed by shareholders at extraordinary general meeting on May 23, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: This resolution was affirmed by the shareholders at their extraordinary general meeting held on May 23, 1951

facts.text: Notice of termination issued on April 23, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: In 9-M 1245 SupCI/71 pursuance of the resolution, the Board of Directors on April 23, 1951, a numberice of termination of the managing agency was issued to the managing agents.

facts.text: Assessee claimed compensation of Rs. 50 lacs for unlawful termination.

anchor.surface_text: In reply the assessee ,claimed companypensation of Rs. 50 lacs for the unlawful termination of its services.

facts.text: Managed company offered Rs. 2,34,000/- as compensation for unexpired period of 3 years 2 months 7 days plus Rs. 4600/- for 23 days of April 1951.

anchor.surface_text: But the managed companypany was prepared to pay Rs. 2,34,000/- as companypensation calculating the companypensation at Rs. 6,000/- a month for the unexpired period of the agency i. e. 3 years 2 months and 7 days and Rs. 4600/- as remuneration for the 23 days of April 1951.

facts.text: Assessee sued managed company in Bombay High Court claiming Rs. 28 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the assessee sued the managed companypany on the original side of the Bombay High Court claiming a sum of Rs. 28 lakhs as companypensation for the unlawful termination of its services.

facts.text: Suit decreed on November 17, 1955 in sum of Rs. 2,34,000/-, affirmed in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was decreed on November 17, 1955 in the sum of Rs. 2,34,000/- and that decree was affirmed in appeal.

facts.text: Assessee received the decreed amount in December 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee received the amount decreed in December, 1955.

facts.text: Assessee maintained accounts according to mercantile system of accountancy.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly the assessee maintained its accounts according to mercantile system of accountancy.,

facts.text: In assessment year 1956-57, ITO included the amount as profits overruling assessee's objections.

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment year 1956-57, the Income-tax Officer overruling the objections of the assessee included the said amount as the profits of the business of the assessee during the previous year.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed with ITO that amount became due on November 17, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal the Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed with the view taken by the Income-tax Officer. He opined that the amount became due to the assessee only when it was decreed by the High Court on November 17, 1955 and therefore it was assessable in the assessment year 1956-57.

facts.text: Tribunal held compensation became due on April 23, 1951, not taxable in 1956-57.

anchor.surface_text: But on a further appeal, the Tribunal held that on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the companypensation in question became due to the assessee on April 23, 1951 and therefore it companyld number be brought to tax in the assessment year 1956-57.

facts.text: Tribunal referred two questions to High Court under s. 66(1).

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner, the Tribunal submitted under s. 66  1  of the Act, the following two questions of law for the opinion of the High Court

facts.text: Bombay High Court answered first question affirmatively (accrued on 23rd April 1951).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in the affirmative

facts.text: High Court held compensation of Rs. 2,34,000/- not liable to tax under s.10(5A) in 1956-57, but interest thereon taxable.

anchor.surface_text: and the second question as follows The amount of companypensation of Rs. 2,34,000/- will number be liable to tax, but the amount of- interest thereon will be taxable under s. 10, 5A  in the assessment year 1956-57

facts.text: S.10(5A) inserted by Finance Act 1955 (Act 15 of 1955), not retrospective.

anchor.surface_text: Till the insertion of S. 10  5A  into the Act by the Finance Act of 1955  Act 15 of 1955 , companypensation received by a managing agent for the termination of his agency was companysidered as a capital receipt, but S. 10  5A  provided that any companypensation or other payment due to or received by a managing agent of an Indian Company at or in companynection with the termination or modification of his managing agency agreement with the companypany shall be deemed to be profits and gains of a business carried on by the managing agent, and shall be liable to tax accordingly. This provision is number retrospective in operation.

facts.text: Termination did not fall within clause 15 of the agreement.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that the termination of the managing agency did number fall within the scope of clause 15 of the agreement

facts.text: Clause 14 provides for liquidated damages equal to aggregate of monthly salary not less than Rs. 6000 for unexpired portion.

anchor.surface_text: That clause provides In case the firm shall be deprived of the office of Agents of the. companypany for any reason or cause other than or except those reasons or causes specified in clause fifteen of these presents the firm shall be entitled to receive from the Company as companypensation or liquidated damages for the loss of such appointment a sum equal to the aggregate amount of the monthly salary of number less than Rupees six thousand, which the Firm would have been entitled to receive from the companypany for and during the whole of the then unexpired portion of the said period of twenty one years if the said Agency of the Firm had number been determined.

facts.text: In the suit, High Court held assessee entitled only to Rs.6000 per month liquidated damages.

anchor.surface_text: The trial judge as well as the appellate Bench held that under the terms of the agreement the assessee was only entitled to liquidated damages at the rate of Rs. 6,000/- per month for the unexpired term of its agency.

facts.text: Supreme Court agreed that compensation became due on April 23, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Hence we agree with the answer given by the High Court to the first question referred to earlier.

facts.text: Assessee's right to compensation arose in April 1951 under mercantile system.

anchor.surface_text: We have already held that it arose in April 1951.

anchor.surface_text: That clause provides In case the firm shall be deprived of the office of Agents of the. company for any reason or cause other than or except those reasons or causes specified in clause fifteen of these presents the firm shall be entitled to receive from the Company as compensation or liquidated damages for the loss of such appointment a sum equal to the aggregate amount of the monthly salary of not less than Rupees six thousand...

arguments.claim: "due to" in s.10(5A) applies to mercantile system assessees; "received by" to cash system

anchor.surface_text: Now arises the question to what circumstance the expression due to in s. 10 5A applies and to what circumstance the expression received therein is applicable? They do not mean the same thing. ... the expression due to in that section refers to those assessees who maintain their accounts according to the mercantile system of accountancy and the expression received by applies to those assessees who adopt the cash system of accountancy.

arguments.claim: Dispute over quantum does not prevent accrual if right and amount fixed by contract

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accede to this contention. As mentioned earlier, the right of the assessee to get compensation for unlawful termination of its services and the quantum of compensation to which it was entitled were clearly prescribed in the agreement. ... The fact that the assessee was claiming an ex- orbitant sum to, which it was not entitled to will not convert its right into a contingent right.

arguments.claim: s.10(5A) must be read with other Act provisions on accountancy systems

anchor.surface_text: That law permits an assessee to adopt his own system of accountancy subject to certain conditions and his tax liability is determined on the basis of the system of accountancy adopted by him. ... We have to read, s. 10 5A alongwith the other provisions in the Act.

arguments.claim: Precedent in Thiagaraja Chettiar applies: remuneration accrues despite disputes if contractually due

anchor.surface_text: In Thiagaraja Chettiar Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras the High Court of Madras held that where a managing agent is entitled under the terms of the managing agency agreement to remuneration at a certain percentage on the annual net profits of the company, the remuneration payable to the managing agent accrued when the net profits of the company for the year are ascertained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compensation due in 1951 under mercantile system; s.10(5A) uses 'due to or received by' distinguished by accountancy method; provision not retrospective; interest accrues later

holdings.text: The expression 'due to' in s. 10(5A) refers to assessees maintaining accounts on mercantile system and 'received by' to those on cash system

anchor.surface_text: Now arises the question to what circumstance the expression due to in s. 10 5A applies and to what circumstance the expression received therein is applicable? They do not mean the same thing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.10(5A) read with Act provisions permitting choice of accountancy system; mercantile recognizes accrual (due), cash actual receipt; consistent with Gajapathy Naidu

holdings.text: Assessee's right to compensation arose in April 1951 under mercantile system despite dispute over quantum

anchor.surface_text: We have already held that it arose in April 1951.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract fixes right and minimum quantum; exorbitant claim does not make contingent; Thiagaraja Chettiar precedent: remuneration accrues despite disputes if contractually due

holdings.text: s.10(5A) is to be read along with other provisions of the Act on system of accountancy

anchor.surface_text: That law permits an assessee to adopt his own system of accountancy subject to certain conditions and his tax liability is determined on the basis of the system of accountancy adopted by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provision integral part of Act; no standalone code ignoring general accountancy rules; assessee's adopted method governs

holdings.text: Under clause 14 assessee entitled to liquidated damages of definite sum equal to Rs 6000 per month for unexpired portion

anchor.surface_text: It is plain from the language of clause 14 of the agreement that the assessee was entitled to a definite sum under that clause. In other words it was entitled to liquidated damages.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language quantifies damages as aggregate monthly salary not less than Rs 6000 for unexpired 21 years; not linked to clause 10 profits; High Court suit affirmed

holdings.text: Dispute over quantum does not prevent accrual of right if fixed by contract

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accede to this contention. As mentioned earlier, the right of the assessee to get compensation for unlawful termination of its services and the quantum of compensation to which it was entitled were clearly prescribed in the agreement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exorbitant claim irrelevant; right and quantum prescribed; follows Thiagaraja Chettiar and Hardcastle

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. A. Gajapathy Naidu  1

anchor.surface_text: As observed by this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. A. Gajapathy Naidu  1  When an Income-tax Officer proceeds to include a particular income in the assessment, he should ask himself, inter alia, two questions, namely  1  what is the system of accountancy adopted by the assessee, and  ii  if it is the mercantile system, subject to the deeming provisions, when has the right to receive accrued.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Madras v A Gajapathy Naidu
precedents.cited_proposition: Under mercantile system of accountancy, income should be assessed in the year the right to receive accrues.
precedents.cited_holding: When an Income-tax Officer proceeds to include a particular income in the assessment, he should ask himself, inter alia, two questions, namely (1) what is the system of accountancy adopted by the assessee, and (ii) if it is the mercantile system, subject to the deeming provisions, when has the right to receive accrued.

precedents.citation: Thiagaraja Chettiar Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 2

anchor.surface_text: In Thiagaraja Chettiar Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 2  the High Court of Madras held that where a managing agent is entitled under the terms of the managing agency agreement to remuneration at a certain percentage on the annual net profits of the companypany, the remuneration payable to the managing agent accrued when the net pro-fits  1  53 I.T.R. 114.  2  51. I.T.R. 393, of the companypany for the year are ascertained.

precedents.case_name: Thiagaraja Chettiar Co v Commissioner of Income-tax Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Remuneration due to managing agent accrues on ascertainment of net profits despite disputes or non-crediting in accounts.
precedents.cited_holding: where a managing agent is entitled under the terms of the managing agency agreement to remuneration at a certain percentage on the annual net profits of the company, the remuneration payable to the managing agent accrued when the net profits of the company for the year are ascertained. The mere fact that owing to disputes between the company and the managing agent the company had not credited the managing agent with the remuneration due to the latter in its accounts, would not entitle the managing agent to claim that the remuneration due to him had not accrued

precedents.citation: F. E. Hardosstle Co.  Private  Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay City-1 1

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with the ratio of that decision and that ratio governs the facts of the president case. The ratio of the decision of the Bombay High Court in F. E. Hardosstle Co.  Private  Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay City-1 1 , is also to the same effect.

precedents.case_name: F E Hardosstle Co Private Ltd v Commissioner of Income Tax Bombay City
precedents.cited_proposition: Ratio similar to Thiagaraja Chettiar case regarding accrual of income despite disputes.
